Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They hear that a community member is feeling down and occasionally check in with a kind word.
Story: It’s Sunday afternoon, and I’m sitting in my office at the church, scrolling through my phone. I see a text from my mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Miss you.” I haven’t called her in a week, just sent a quick text yesterday. Guilt pricks at me—she always wants to hear my voice, not just read a line or two. But before I can reply, my phone buzzes again. It’s a message from Mrs. Carter, a member of the congregation. She’s been struggling since her husband passed, and I’ve been checking in with her, sending her encouraging words. She writes, “Thank you for your prayers, Pastor. It means a lot.” I know she needs more than a text, maybe a visit or a call, but I only have so much time. My parents expect me to be present, to share my life with them, but my congregation needs me too. I stare at my phone, torn between calling my mom and reaching out to Mrs. Carter, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
